title: Viral Meningitis
scope: ** Diagnosis, supportive management, and follow-up of viral (aseptic) meningitis in adults. Covers empiric antibiotic and antiviral therapy until bacterial meningitis and HSV encephalitis are excluded, viral pathogen identification via CSF PCR and BioFire ME Panel, supportive care (IV fluids, analgesics, antiemetics), differentiation from bacterial meningitis, HIV testing, and discharge criteria. Excludes bacterial meningitis (separate template), HSV encephalitis (separate template), fungal meningitis, tuberculous meningitis, drug-induced aseptic meningitis, and neonatal/pediatric meningitis.

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Infection screen; leukocytosis may be mild or absent in viral meningitis; helps differentiate from bacterial (marked leukocytosis with left shift)
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal or mild leukocytosis; lymphocyte predominance favors viral

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Renal function for medication dosing (acyclovir); electrolytes (SIADH risk); hepatic function baseline
MUST be drawn BEFORE empiric antibiotics; exclude concurrent bacteremia; positive blood cultures argue against isolated viral meningitis
Highly useful for distinguishing bacterial from viral meningitis; procalcitonin <0.5 ng/mL strongly argues against bacterial etiology (negative predictive value >95%)
Essential/Core Labs.target: Low (<0.5 ng/mL favors viral; >2.0 ng/mL favors bacterial)

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Inflammatory marker; typically lower in viral than bacterial meningitis; helps monitor clinical course
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal to mildly elevated (markedly elevated suggests bacterial)

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Calculate CSF:serum glucose ratio; normal ratio (>0.6) expected in viral meningitis; low ratio (<0.4) suggests bacterial, TB, or fungal
Essential/Core Labs.target: Pair with CSF glucose; CSF:serum ratio >0.6 expected

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Pre-LP coagulopathy screen; sepsis-associated DIC risk if bacterial meningitis not yet excluded
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal (coagulopathy argues against benign viral process)

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Sepsis screening; elevated serum lactate suggests systemic bacterial infection rather than viral meningitis

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: ALL patients with viral meningitis should be tested for HIV; acute HIV seroconversion is an important cause of aseptic meningitis (present in 10-17% of acute HIV); missed HIV has major treatment implications
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Negative; if positive, obtain viral load and CD4 count

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: If acute HIV seroconversion suspected (high-risk exposure, rash, pharyngitis, lymphadenopathy); antibody test may be negative early
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Negative; if positive, confirms acute HIV infection

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: SIADH assessment (can occur with any meningitis, though less common in viral than bacterial)
Thyroid dysfunction in altered mental status differential
Neurosyphilis can mimic viral meningitis with lymphocytic CSF; screen in sexually active adults

Extended Workup (Second-line).item: Hepatitis B surface antigen, Hepatitis C antibody
Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Concurrent viral hepatitis screen; shared risk factors with HIV; affects management
EBV meningitis in differential (infectious mononucleosis); pharyngitis, lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly
Sarcoidosis (neurosarcoidosis mimics chronic aseptic meningitis); obtain if recurrent or atypical

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.item: Arboviral serologies (West Nile IgM/IgG, Eastern equine, St. Louis encephalitis)
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Seasonal (summer-fall); geographic risk; mosquito exposure; West Nile virus can cause meningitis in addition to encephalitis
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.target: Negative; if positive, confirms arboviral etiology (supportive care only)

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: If immunocompromised (HIV, transplant, chronic steroids); chronic meningitis presentation; headache predominant
TB meningitis in differential (subacute, basilar, low glucose); high-risk populations (immigrants, HIV, incarcerated)
If fungal meningitis suspected (immunocompromised, chronic presentation)
If recurrent aseptic meningitis or encephalitic features; NMDAR, LGI1, CASPR2 antibodies
Recurrent meningitis; complement deficiency predisposes to Neisseria infection
Recurrent meningitis; hypogammaglobulinemia predisposes to recurrent infections

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Usually normal or mildly elevated in viral meningitis; markedly elevated suggests bacterial, fungal, or TB meningitis
Lumbar Puncture.target: Normal to mildly elevated (10-25 cm H2O); >30 cm H2O uncommon in viral — consider alternative diagnosis

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: HALLMARK: Lymphocytic pleocytosis; tube 1 vs 4 comparison differentiates traumatic tap; early viral meningitis (<48h) may show neutrophil predominance that shifts to lymphocytes on repeat LP
Lumbar Puncture.target: WBC 10-500 cells/uL with lymphocyte predominance (>50%); NOTE: early viral meningitis may have neutrophil predominance in first 24-48h

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Mildly elevated in viral meningitis; markedly elevated (>200 mg/dL) suggests bacterial, TB, or fungal
Lumbar Puncture.target: Normal to mildly elevated (50-100 mg/dL); >200 mg/dL argues against simple viral meningitis

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: NORMAL glucose is key differentiator from bacterial meningitis; CSF:serum ratio >0.6 expected in viral
Lumbar Puncture.target: Normal (>40 mg/dL; CSF:serum ratio >0.6); LOW glucose (<40 or ratio <0.4) argues strongly against viral — consider bacterial, TB, fungal, or carcinomatous meningitis

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Rule out bacterial meningitis; should be NEGATIVE in viral meningitis
Lumbar Puncture.target: No organisms seen (negative Gram stain expected)

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Gold standard to exclude bacterial meningitis; negative cultures at 48-72h help confirm viral etiology
Lumbar Puncture.target: No growth at 48-72h (expected in viral meningitis)

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Rapid multiplex PCR (~1 hour turnaround); identifies 14 pathogens: 6 bacteria (E. coli K1, H. influenzae, L. monocytogenes, N. meningitidis, S. agalactiae, S. pneumoniae), 7 viruses (CMV, enterovirus, HSV-1, HSV-2, HHV-6, parechovirus, VZV), and Cryptococcus neoformans/gattii
Lumbar Puncture.target: Viral pathogen identified (most commonly enterovirus); negative for bacterial pathogens allows de-escalation of empiric antibiotics

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Most common cause of viral meningitis (50-80% of identified cases); summer-fall seasonality; rapid confirmation allows discontinuation of empiric antibiotics and acyclovir
Lumbar Puncture.target: Positive in enteroviral meningitis; negative does not exclude viral etiology

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: CRITICAL: Exclude HSV encephalitis (treatable and fatal if missed); HSV-2 causes benign recurrent (Mollaret) meningitis
Lumbar Puncture.target: Negative (positive HSV-1 → treat as HSV encephalitis; positive HSV-2 → Mollaret meningitis, consider suppressive therapy)

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: VZV meningitis can occur with or without rash (zoster sine herpete); immunocompromised patients at higher risk
Lumbar Puncture.target: Negative; if positive → IV acyclovir treatment indicated

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: CSF lactate <3.5 mmol/L strongly argues against bacterial meningitis (sensitivity ~93%, specificity ~96%); valuable when Gram stain negative and clinical picture unclear
Summer-fall; mosquito exposure; elderly; flaccid paralysis; encephalitic features
Lumbar Puncture.target: Negative; if positive, confirms WNV neuroinvasive disease (supportive care)

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: If immunocompromised (HIV, transplant); subacute or chronic meningitis
If malignancy in differential (subacute, cranial neuropathies, known cancer)
Neurosyphilis screen; lymphocytic CSF with normal glucose
If TB meningitis suspected (subacute presentation, basilar enhancement, low glucose, high protein, immigrant/HIV)

Essential/First-line.timing: ONLY if LP delay indications present (see Contraindications to LP below). Do NOT delay empiric antibiotics for CT. CT BEFORE LP only if: immunocompromised, history of CNS disease, new seizure within 1 week, papilledema, altered consciousness (GCS <10), focal neurologic deficit
Essential/First-line.target: Normal in viral meningitis (rules out mass effect, hydrocephalus, abscess before LP)
Essential/First-line.contraindications: Pregnancy (relative); CT is NOT required before LP in all patients — only if specific indications present

Essential/First-line.target: Baseline; rule out QTc prolongation before antiemetics (ondansetron)

Extended.item: MRI brain with and without contrast (CPT 70553)
Extended.timing: Within 24-48h if: altered mental status, focal deficits, seizures, encephalitic features, or failure to improve; STAT if encephalitis suspected
Extended.target: Normal in uncomplicated viral meningitis; meningeal enhancement (non-specific); temporal lobe T2/FLAIR signal suggests HSV encephalitis; hydrocephalus

Extended.timing: If altered mental status, seizures, or encephalitic features
Extended.target: Normal background or mild diffuse slowing; focal findings or PLEDs suggest encephalitis rather than meningitis

Extended.timing: If respiratory symptoms; rule out concurrent pneumonia

Rare/Specialized.timing: If recurrent meningitis (rule out CSF leak, skull base defect)
If myelitic symptoms (weakness, bowel/bladder dysfunction); rule out concurrent myelitis
Rare/Specialized.target: Normal; spinal cord signal change suggests myelitis

Rare/Specialized.timing: If persistent altered consciousness; concern for non-convulsive seizures

Acute/Emergent.item: Ceftriaxone IV (empiric — until bacterial meningitis excluded) (CPT 96374)
Acute/Emergent.indication: Empiric bacterial coverage; covers S. pneumoniae, N. meningitidis, H. influenzae, gram-negatives; continue until CSF cultures negative at 48-72h and BioFire negative for bacteria

doseOptions.orderSentence: Ceftriaxone IV (empiric — until bacterial meningitis excluded) (CPT 96374) 2 g IV

dosing.instructions: 2 g IV q12h; start within 30 minutes of presentation; discontinue when bacterial meningitis excluded (negative Gram stain + negative BioFire + CSF consistent with viral + cultures negative at 48-72h)
dosing.orderSentence: Ceftriaxone IV (empiric — until bacterial meningitis excluded) (CPT 96374) 2 g IV

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Cephalosporin allergy (true anaphylaxis — use chloramphenicol or meropenem as alternative)
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: CBC; LFTs; biliary sludge with prolonged use

Acute/Emergent.item: Vancomycin IV (empiric — until bacterial meningitis excluded) (CPT 96365)
Acute/Emergent.indication: Covers penicillin-resistant S. pneumoniae and MRSA; essential component of empiric bacterial meningitis coverage

doseOptions.orderSentence: Vancomycin IV (empiric — until bacterial meningitis excluded) (CPT 96365) 15-20 mg/kg IV

dosing.instructions: 15-20 mg/kg IV q8-12h (target trough 15-20 ug/mL or AUC/MIC 400-600); loading dose 25-30 mg/kg if severe; discontinue when bacterial meningitis excluded
dosing.orderSentence: Vancomycin IV (empiric — until bacterial meningitis excluded) (CPT 96365) 15-20 mg/kg IV

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Red man syndrome (infuse over 1h minimum); renal impairment (dose adjust)
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Trough levels before 4th dose; renal function daily; watch nephrotoxicity and ototoxicity

Acute/Emergent.item: Ampicillin IV (add if age >50, immunocompromised, or alcoholism) (CPT 96374)
Acute/Emergent.indication: Covers Listeria monocytogenes (resistant to cephalosporins); add to vancomycin + ceftriaxone if risk factors present: age >50, immunocompromised, alcoholism, pregnancy

doseOptions.orderSentence: Ampicillin IV (add if age >50, immunocompromised, or alcoholism) (CPT 96374) 2 g IV

dosing.instructions: 2 g IV q4h; discontinue when bacterial meningitis excluded and Listeria not identified
dosing.orderSentence: Ampicillin IV (add if age >50, immunocompromised, or alcoholism) (CPT 96374) 2 g IV

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Penicillin anaphylaxis (use TMP-SMX as Listeria alternative)

Acute/Emergent.indication: CRITICAL: Empiric HSV coverage; HSV encephalitis is fatal if untreated; start on ALL patients with meningitis until HSV PCR returns negative and no encephalitic features present

doseOptions.orderSentence: Acyclovir IV (empiric — until HSV excluded) (CPT 96365) 10 mg/kg IV

dosing.instructions: 10 mg/kg IV q8h (based on ideal body weight); infuse over 1h; discontinue when HSV PCR negative AND no encephalitic features (confusion, focal deficits, seizures, temporal lobe MRI changes). CrCl 25-50: q12h; CrCl 10-25: q24h
dosing.orderSentence: Acyclovir IV (empiric — until HSV excluded) (CPT 96365) 10 mg/kg IV

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Renal impairment (dose adjust; do NOT withhold)
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Renal function (BUN, Cr) daily; ensure adequate hydration (1 mL/kg/h); urine output; acyclovir crystal nephropathy risk

Acute/Emergent.item: Dexamethasone (adjunctive — give BEFORE or WITH first antibiotic dose)
Acute/Emergent.indication: Give empirically with antibiotics; greatest benefit if bacterial meningitis (especially S. pneumoniae); discontinue when bacterial meningitis excluded

doseOptions.orderSentence: Dexamethasone (adjunctive — give BEFORE or WITH first antibiotic dose) 0.15 mg/kg IV

dosing.instructions: 0.15 mg/kg IV q6h (typically 10 mg IV q6h) x 4 days; MUST be given BEFORE or simultaneously with first antibiotic dose; discontinue when bacterial meningitis excluded; no proven benefit in viral meningitis
dosing.orderSentence: Dexamethasone (adjunctive — give BEFORE or WITH first antibiotic dose) 0.15 mg/kg IV

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Not beneficial if antibiotics already started >1h prior
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Glucose q6h; GI prophylaxis; blood pressure

Acute/Emergent.indication: Volume resuscitation; maintain hydration for acyclovir clearance (prevent crystal nephropathy); correct dehydration from poor oral intake, vomiting

dosing.instructions: 1-1.5 mL/kg/h continuous maintenance; bolus 500-1000 mL if dehydrated or hypotensive

Acute/Emergent.monitoring: I/O; electrolytes q6-12h; watch for SIADH (fluid restrict if Na <130)

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Headache and fever reduction; first-line analgesic and antipyretic for viral meningitis

dosing.instructions: 650-1000 mg PO/IV q6h; max 4 g/day; IV formulation for patients unable to take PO

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Severe hepatic disease (Child-Pugh C); acetaminophen allergy
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Temperature; LFTs if prolonged use; total daily dose

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Headache and fever; anti-inflammatory for meningeal inflammation; may be more effective than acetaminophen alone for meningitis headache

dosing.instructions: 400-600 mg PO q6h with food; max 2400 mg/day; use in combination with acetaminophen for refractory headache

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Renal impairment; GI bleed risk; coagulopathy; allergy; dehydration
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Renal function; GI symptoms; avoid if not adequately hydrated

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Severe headache refractory to oral analgesics; potent anti-inflammatory; short-term use only

dosing.instructions: 15-30 mg IV q6h (15 mg if age >65, renal impairment, or weight <50 kg); max 5 days; transition to oral NSAID

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Renal impairment; GI bleed; coagulopathy; age >65 (dose reduce); concurrent anticoagulants
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Renal function daily; GI symptoms; limit to 5 days maximum

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Nausea and vomiting (common with meningitis; worsened by meningeal irritation)

dosing.instructions: 4 mg IV/PO q6h PRN; may increase to 8 mg q6h if refractory

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: QT prolongation; congenital long QT syndrome
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: QTc if risk factors or concurrent QT-prolonging medications

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Nausea refractory to ondansetron; also has prokinetic effect

dosing.instructions: 10 mg IV q6-8h PRN; max 30 days use (tardive dyskinesia risk)

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Parkinson disease; history of tardive dyskinesia; bowel obstruction; pheochromocytoma

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Nausea and vomiting refractory to ondansetron; also effective for headache with nausea

dosing.instructions: 5-10 mg IV q6-8h PRN; max 40 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Parkinson disease; seizure history (lowers threshold); QT prolongation

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Maintain hydration during period of poor oral intake; support acyclovir clearance; replace insensible losses from fever

dosing.instructions: 75-125 mL/h 0.9% normal saline or LR; adjust based on I/O and clinical status

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: GI prophylaxis if receiving dexamethasone or if critical illness

dosing.instructions: 40 mg IV/PO daily; discontinue when dexamethasone stopped

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: C. diff risk with prolonged use

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Severe headache refractory to acetaminophen + NSAIDs; use sparingly and short-term only; avoid in patients who can tolerate oral analgesics

dosing.instructions: 2-4 mg IV q3-4h PRN; titrate to pain relief; minimize use; transition to non-opioid regimen as soon as possible

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: Respiratory depression; altered mental status; opioid allergy; ileus
Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: Respiratory rate; sedation level; pain scores; bowel function

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Suppressive antiviral therapy for recurrent HSV-2 meningitis (Mollaret meningitis); reduces frequency and severity of recurrences

doseOptions.orderSentence: Valacyclovir (for HSV-2 Mollaret meningitis) 500 mg PO

dosing.instructions: 500 mg PO BID or 1000 mg PO daily for suppressive therapy; duration individualized (months to years); discuss risk/benefit with patient
dosing.orderSentence: Valacyclovir (for HSV-2 Mollaret meningitis) 500 mg PO

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: Renal impairment (dose adjust); thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (rare, high dose)
Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: Renal function at baseline and periodically; CBC if prolonged use

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Targeted therapy for VZV meningitis (with or without rash); immunocompromised patients require IV therapy; immunocompetent may be treated with oral valacyclovir if mild

doseOptions.orderSentence: Acyclovir IV (for confirmed VZV meningitis) 10 mg/kg IV

dosing.instructions: 10 mg/kg IV q8h (based on ideal body weight) x 10-14 days; transition to oral valacyclovir 1000 mg PO TID when clinically improving
dosing.orderSentence: Acyclovir IV (for confirmed VZV meningitis) 10 mg/kg IV

Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: Renal function daily; adequate hydration; urine output

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Oral step-down for VZV meningitis in immunocompetent patients who are clinically improving; total treatment duration 10-14 days

doseOptions.orderSentence: Valacyclovir (for VZV meningitis — oral step-down) 1000 mg PO

dosing.instructions: 1000 mg PO TID; complete total 10-14 day course (combined IV + PO)
dosing.orderSentence: Valacyclovir (for VZV meningitis — oral step-down) 1000 mg PO

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Seizure management if seizures develop (uncommon in uncomplicated viral meningitis; suggests encephalitis component); NOT routine prophylaxis

dosing.instructions: 1000-1500 mg IV load then 500-1000 mg IV/PO BID; max 3000 mg/day

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Active seizure rescue; rare in isolated viral meningitis; more common if encephalitis component

dosing.instructions: 0.1 mg/kg IV (max 4 mg); may repeat x1 in 5 min

Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: Respiratory rate; SpO2; airway equipment ready

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Elevated ICP management (rare in viral meningitis; suggests alternative diagnosis or complication)

dosing.instructions: 1-1.5 g/kg IV bolus; then 0.25-0.5 g/kg q4-6h

Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: Serum osmolality (<320); osmolar gap; renal function; I/O

Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies.indication: Chronic suppressive therapy for recurrent HSV-2 meningitis (Mollaret meningitis); initiate after second or third recurrence; reduces frequency of episodes

doseOptions.orderSentence: Valacyclovir (chronic suppression for Mollaret meningitis) 500 mg PO

dosing.instructions: 500 mg PO BID or 1000 mg PO daily; continue for 6-12 months then reassess; some patients require indefinite suppression
dosing.orderSentence: Valacyclovir (chronic suppression for Mollaret meningitis) 500 mg PO

Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies.pretreatment: Confirm HSV-2 by CSF PCR during acute episode; baseline renal function; educate patient on adherence and expected benefit
Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies.contraindications: Renal impairment (dose adjust CrCl <30: 500 mg daily); TTP/HUS (rare, high-dose)
Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies.monitoring: Renal function q3-6 months; CBC annually; symptom recurrence diary

Referrals & Consults.item: Infectious disease consultation for all cases with unclear etiology, immunocompromised host, HIV-positive patient, or recurrent meningitis to guide pathogen identification and management
Neurology consultation if altered mental status, seizures, focal neurologic deficits, or encephalitic features are present to differentiate meningitis from encephalitis and guide management
Neurology follow-up in 2-4 weeks for post-meningitis headache management and cognitive assessment
Primary care follow-up in 1-2 weeks after discharge for symptom reassessment, medication review, and lab follow-up (HIV results, other pending studies)
HIV specialist/infectious disease referral if new HIV diagnosis to initiate antiretroviral therapy and long-term management
Immunology referral for recurrent meningitis (2 or more episodes) to evaluate for complement deficiency, hypogammaglobulinemia, or anatomic CSF leak
ENT/Otolaryngology referral if recurrent meningitis with suspected CSF leak (rhinorrhea, otorrhea, skull base defect) for surgical evaluation and repair
Psychiatry or psychology referral for persistent mood or cognitive symptoms following meningitis (post-infectious fatigue, depression, anxiety, difficulty concentrating)

Patient Instructions.item: Return to ED immediately if: worsening headache, new confusion or personality change, seizure, high fever (>39C/102.2F), new rash (especially petechial/purpuric), neck stiffness worsening, vision changes, new weakness — these may indicate bacterial meningitis or encephalitis
Viral meningitis is usually self-limited and resolves in 7-10 days; headache and fatigue may persist for 2-4 weeks during recovery
Stay well-hydrated (drink at least 2 liters of fluids daily) to support recovery and prevent dehydration
Take acetaminophen and/or ibuprofen on a scheduled basis (not PRN) for the first 3-5 days to control headache and fever; taper as symptoms improve
Avoid bright lights and loud environments if photophobia and phonophobia persist (dim rooms and sunglasses may help)
Rest in a quiet, dark room; gradual return to activity over 1-2 weeks as symptoms improve; avoid strenuous exercise until headache-free
Enteroviral meningitis is mildly contagious via fecal-oral route; practice good hand hygiene (handwashing after bathroom use) for 2 weeks to prevent transmission to household contacts
Follow up with primary care in 1-2 weeks; follow up with neurology if persistent headache, cognitive symptoms, or new neurologic symptoms develop
Report any recurrent episodes of headache with fever and neck stiffness (recurrent meningitis requires additional workup for underlying cause)

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Hand hygiene education (handwashing with soap for 20 seconds, especially after bathroom use) to prevent enteroviral transmission

Mosquito bite prevention (DEET-containing repellent, protective clothing, screen windows) for patients in arboviral-endemic areas during summer-fall season to reduce West Nile virus and other arboviral meningitis risk
HIV testing and prevention counseling for all patients with viral meningitis (acute HIV is an important cause of aseptic meningitis)
Ensure up-to-date vaccination (MMR, varicella) to prevent vaccine-preventable causes of viral meningitis (mumps, measles)
Avoid close contact with individuals who have hand-foot-mouth disease or known enteroviral illness during outbreaks (especially pregnant women, immunocompromised, neonates)
Smoking cessation to support immune function and reduce upper respiratory infection risk
Adequate sleep (7-9 hours per night) and stress management during recovery period to support immune function
For patients with Mollaret (recurrent HSV-2) meningitis: discuss suppressive antiviral therapy with neurology/infectious disease to reduce recurrence frequency
Avoid sharing eating utensils, drinking glasses, and towels during acute illness to prevent enteroviral transmission to household contacts
Pneumococcal and meningococcal vaccination review to ensure up-to-date status (does NOT prevent viral meningitis but prevents future bacterial meningitis risk)
Safe sexual practices counseling for patients with HSV-2 meningitis (Mollaret) to reduce transmission risk and inform partners

differential.features: More toxic appearance; higher fever; rapid deterioration; CSF: neutrophilic pleocytosis (WBC >1000), low glucose (CSF:serum <0.4), very high protein (>100 mg/dL), positive Gram stain (60-90%); procalcitonin >2.0 ng/mL; CSF lactate >3.5 mmol/L
differential.tests: CSF Gram stain, culture, BioFire ME Panel; procalcitonin; CSF lactate; CSF glucose

differential.features: Encephalitis features (confusion, personality change, focal deficits, seizures); temporal lobe predilection on MRI; PLEDs on EEG; CSF may be hemorrhagic (RBCs); more altered mental status than isolated meningitis
differential.tests: MRI brain (temporal lobe T2/FLAIR signal); CSF HSV PCR; EEG (PLEDs); clinical features (confusion, seizures, focal deficits)

differential.features: Subacute onset (weeks); basilar meningitis with cranial neuropathies; CSF: lymphocytic but LOW glucose, very HIGH protein (100-500 mg/dL); TB risk factors (immigrant, HIV, incarcerated)
differential.tests: AFB smear/culture; TB PCR (GeneXpert); CSF ADA (>8 IU/L); chest imaging; QuantiFERON; clinical chronicity

differential.features: Subacute/chronic; immunocompromised (HIV with CD4 <100); headache predominant; minimal pleocytosis; elevated opening pressure
differential.tests: CSF cryptococcal antigen (CrAg); India ink; fungal culture; serum CrAg

differential.features: Fever, headache, pharyngitis, rash, lymphadenopathy, myalgias 2-4 weeks after exposure; CSF lymphocytic pleocytosis; antibody test may be negative (window period)
differential.tests: HIV RNA viral load (positive before antibody); 4th-gen Ag/Ab test; detailed sexual/exposure history

differential.features: Temporal relationship with offending drug (NSAIDs, IVIG, TMP-SMX, isoniazid, azathioprine, OKT3); resolves with drug withdrawal; recurs with rechallenge
differential.tests: Medication history review; drug withdrawal with resolution; sterile CSF cultures; re-exposure reproduces symptoms

differential.features: Thunderclap headache (worst headache of life); NOT typically febrile initially; meningismus from blood irritation; xanthochromia; RBCs on CSF
differential.tests: CT head (blood in subarachnoid space); CSF xanthochromia; RBCs equal in tubes 1 and 4; CTA if SAH confirmed

differential.features: Subacute; psychiatric symptoms (psychosis, agitation); orofacial dyskinesias; seizures; young women; fever may occur; MRI may be normal or show temporal changes
differential.tests: Autoimmune antibody panel (serum + CSF); NMDAR, LGI1, CASPR2; MRI; EEG; ovarian teratoma screen

differential.features: Subacute; cranial neuropathies; known malignancy; CSF: low glucose, elevated protein, positive cytology; may be recurrent
differential.tests: CSF cytology (repeat x3 for sensitivity); MRI with contrast (leptomeningeal enhancement); flow cytometry

differential.features: Chronic headache; cranial neuropathies (CN VII most common); hilar lymphadenopathy; elevated ACE level; non-caseating granulomas
differential.tests: Chest CT (hilar adenopathy); serum ACE; CSF ACE; biopsy of accessible tissue

differential.features: Recurrent aseptic meningitis; oral and genital ulcers; uveitis; pathergy; Mediterranean/Middle Eastern descent
differential.tests: Clinical criteria (oral ulcers + 2 of: genital ulcers, eye lesions, skin lesions, positive pathergy); HLA-B51

differential.features: Prior antibiotic exposure masking CSF findings; CSF may appear viral (lymphocytic, normal glucose) after partial treatment; cultures negative
differential.tests: Antibiotic history; BioFire ME Panel (may still detect bacterial DNA); clinical trajectory; procalcitonin (remains elevated in bacterial)

evidence.recommendation: Empiric antibiotics and acyclovir until bacterial meningitis and HSV excluded
evidence.source: IDSA Guidelines ([Tunkel et al. CID 2004](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/15494903/)); standard of care — cannot reliably distinguish viral from bacterial meningitis clinically

evidence.recommendation: Enterovirus is the most common cause of viral meningitis (50-80%)
evidence.source: [Sawyer MH. Enterovirus infections: diagnosis and treatment. Semin Pediatr Infect Dis 2002](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/12118843/); [Rotbart HA. Viral meningitis. Semin Neurol 2000](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/11051293/)

evidence.recommendation: BioFire ME Panel for rapid pathogen identification (~1 hour)
evidence.source: [Leber et al. JCM 2016](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/27335149/); FDA-cleared multiplex PCR with high sensitivity/specificity; enables rapid de-escalation of empiric therapy

evidence.recommendation: CSF lactate <3.5 mmol/L to distinguish viral from bacterial meningitis
evidence.source: Meta-analysis: [Sakushima et al. J Infect 2011](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/21382412/) — sensitivity 93%, specificity 96% for bacterial meningitis

evidence.recommendation: Procalcitonin <0.5 ng/mL argues against bacterial meningitis
evidence.source: Meta-analysis: [Wei et al. PLoS One 2016](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/27992557/); [Vikse et al. BMC Infect Dis 2015](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/26469559/) — high NPV for excluding bacterial meningitis

evidence.recommendation: HIV testing in all cases of aseptic meningitis
evidence.source: CDC recommendations; acute HIV seroconversion causes 10-17% of aseptic meningitis in some series ([Kellinghaus et al. Eur J Neurol 2008](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/18707021/))

evidence.recommendation: CSF findings in viral meningitis (lymphocytic pleocytosis, normal glucose)
evidence.source: Standard diagnostic criteria; [Logan & MacMahon. BMJ 2008](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/18174598/) — comprehensive review of meningitis CSF patterns

evidence.recommendation: Early neutrophilic predominance in viral meningitis (first 24-48h)
evidence.source: [Negrini et al. BMC Infect Dis 2000](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/10929031/); up to 60% of enteroviral meningitis shows neutrophil predominance early — repeat LP in 12-24h shows lymphocytic shift

evidence.recommendation: Supportive care (fluids, analgesics, antiemetics) as primary treatment
evidence.source: Standard of care; no antiviral therapy improves outcomes for enteroviral meningitis; [Desmond et al. CID 2006](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/18634700/)

evidence.recommendation: Valacyclovir suppressive therapy for recurrent HSV-2 (Mollaret) meningitis
evidence.source: Expert consensus; [Aurelius et al. Scand J Infect Dis 1991](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/1670839/); limited RCT data but widely used in practice

evidence.recommendation: CT before LP only for specific indications (not all patients)
evidence.source: [Hasbun et al. NEJM 2001](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/11742046/) — criteria for when CT is needed before LP; routine CT delays diagnosis unnecessarily

evidence.recommendation: Dexamethasone adjunctive therapy (for bacterial meningitis coverage)
evidence.source: [de Gans & van de Beek NEJM 2002](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/12432041/) — reduces mortality and hearing loss in S. pneumoniae; given empirically before etiology known

evidence.recommendation: Acyclovir nephrotoxicity prevention with aggressive hydration
evidence.source: Well-established pharmacology; crystal nephropathy prevention; [Izzedine et al. Am J Kidney Dis 2005](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/15861345/)

evidence.recommendation: Viral meningitis is self-limited in immunocompetent adults (7-10 days)
evidence.source: Multiple prospective studies; [McGill et al. Lancet Infect Dis 2018](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/30153934/) — comprehensive review of viral meningitis outcomes

monitoring.item: Neurologic exam (GCS, orientation, meningismus, focal deficits)
monitoring.frequency: q4h in ED/HOSP; q1-2h in ICU; at each OPD visit
monitoring.action: If GCS declining or focal deficits develop: STAT MRI to rule out encephalitis, abscess, or other complication; reassess diagnosis
If persistent fever >72h: consider alternative diagnosis (bacterial, partially treated, abscess); repeat cultures; imaging

monitoring.frequency: q4h in ED/HOSP; at each OPD visit
monitoring.action: If worsening headache: repeat neuroimaging; check for hydrocephalus, elevated ICP; reassess diagnosis
If <130: suspect SIADH; fluid restriction 1-1.2 L/day; if <120: 3% saline; recheck q4-6h
If rising: increase IV hydration; consider dose adjustment; ensure urine output >0.5 mL/kg/h
If positive: bacterial meningitis confirmed; continue antibiotics and escalate management per bacterial meningitis protocol
If positive: transition to targeted antibiotic therapy per bacterial meningitis protocol
If positive: urgent HIV specialist referral; CD4 count; viral load; initiate antiretroviral therapy discussion; ensure linkage to care

monitoring.frequency: q4h in HOSP; at each OPD visit
monitoring.action: If refractory headache persists >2 weeks: neurology referral; evaluate for post-meningitis headache syndrome; consider prophylactic headache treatment

monitoring.frequency: q shift in HOSP; daily in ICU
monitoring.action: If unable to tolerate PO: continue IV fluids; assess for vomiting control; delay discharge until PO tolerance established

monitoring.frequency: Continuous in ICU; q4h on floor
monitoring.action: If declining: supplemental O2; assess for aspiration, pulmonary embolism; reassess need for ICU

monitoring.frequency: q shift in HOSP; q1h in ICU
monitoring.action: If oliguria: increase IV fluids; assess renal function; consider acyclovir dose adjustment
If persistent symptoms at 2-4 weeks: repeat labs (CBC, CRP); consider repeat LP if atypical course; neurology referral
If persistent cognitive complaints: neuropsychological testing; neurology referral; evaluate for post-infectious syndrome

disposition.criteria: ONLY after bacterial meningitis has been sufficiently excluded: negative Gram stain, CSF profile consistent with viral (lymphocytic pleocytosis, normal glucose, protein <100), negative BioFire for bacteria, procalcitonin <0.5, clinically non-toxic, tolerating PO fluids and analgesics, reliable follow-up within 24-48h, responsible adult at home, clear return precautions provided. Blood cultures must be pending with 48h follow-up mechanism (callback system).

Need for neurology/infectious disease expertise not available; need for continuous EEG not available; MRI not available for evaluation of encephalitis

Bacterial meningitis definitively excluded (negative cultures at 48-72h); afebrile >24h; headache controlled with oral analgesics; tolerating oral fluids and medications; GCS 15 with normal neurologic exam; HIV result reviewed; follow-up arranged within 1-2 weeks
PCP visit in 1-2 weeks; neurology if persistent headache or cognitive symptoms at 2-4 weeks; infectious disease if HIV positive or immunocompromised; immunology if recurrent meningitis
Gradual return after symptom improvement (typically 1-2 weeks for mild cases; up to 4 weeks for severe); no driving until headache-free and neurologically intact
